column7: Light forest margins, especially on calcareous soils[74].
column16: Laser trilobum is a PERENNIAL growing to 1.2 m (4ft). The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Insects. The plant is self-fertile.  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils and can grow in very alkaline soils. It can grow in  semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade. It prefers  moist soil.

column19: Seed: includes nuts, cereals, peas and beans.,Stem: this often intergrades into leaves.
column20: Condiment: the various plants that are used as flavourings, either as herbs, spices or condiments.,Drink: not including plant saps, tea or coffee substitutes.
column21: nkThe stem[183] and the seed[2, 105, 177] are said to be edible though no further details are known. The water in which the leaves have been cooked is drunk as a wine and is very refreshing[183]. The seed is used as a condiment[183].

column24: Essential: Essential oils that are used in perfumery, medicines, paint solvents, insect repellents etc.
column25: An essential oil is obtained from the seed and umbels[74].
column27: We have very little information on this plant and do not know if it will be hardy in Britain, though judging by its native range it should succeed outdoors in most areas of the country. It is likely to prefer a well-drained calcareous soil.
column28: Seed - we have no information on this species but suggest sowing the seed in spring in a cold frame. When they are large enough to handle, prick the seedlings out into individual pots and grow them on in the greenhouse for their first winter. Plant them out into their permanent positions in late spring or early summer, after the last expected frosts. Division could be tried in the spring.
